abstracts.cdata!:
The Madagascar Poverty Reduction Support
            Operation Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, substantial institutional
            development, overall satisfactory Bank performance, and
            overall moderately satisfactory Borrower performance. Some
            implications for subsequent operations are: The first year
            of implementation demonstrated the need for continued and
            increased support for public and financial management
            reforms. In particular, increase efforts to strengthen and
            build capacity in the sector ministries for budget
            formulation, procurement, and financial management. Greater
            realism is needed in setting targets and the timeframe.
            Prioritize and scale up the reform process to match the
            Government's capacity. Unpredictability in resource
            flows seriously hampered budget execution during 2004;
            improve predictability through better revenue forecasting. A
            better alignment of donor disbursements with the budget
            cycle might also help improve predictability. A firm
            commitment is actually more relevant than the timing of the
            disbursement; in the case of Madagascar, however, the
            resource availability at the outset is critical in providing
            the level of confidence and certainty needed to execute the
            budget and avoid stop-and-go cycles.
